data.assertion: What does the legal term 'un-indicted co-conspirators' mean?
data.fact:
FACT: On October 20, 2010, Judges Garza, Benavides, and Crone of the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals determined that the U.S. Department of Justice violated the Fifth Amendment rights of the North American Islamic Trust (NAIT), and by implication the rights of more than 240 similarly-named Muslim organizations and individuals when it included them on the publicly-filed unindicted co-conspirator list in 2007. The three-judge federal court of appeals panel was the final arbiter and takes precedence over an earlier ruling by district Judge Jorge Solis.

The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals also ruled that inclusion on the list was the result of "simply an untested allegation of the Government made in anticipation of a possible evidentiary dispute that never came to pass." The listing is simply part of tactical pre-trial maneuvering and not an indicator of guilt.

According to legal experts, there is no legal implication to being labeled an unindicted co-conspirator, since it does not require the Justice Department to prove anything in a court of law. According to Ira Robbins, a law professor at American University's Washington College of Law, "A person named by a federal grand jury as an unindicted co-conspirator does not become a party to the attendant criminal trial, and the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure grant that individual no right to intervene in order to clear his or her name."

On August 8, 2007, Newsweek magazine reported, "According to one senior law-enforcement official (who asked not to be named talking about an ongoing case), the listing of ISNA, CAIR and other groups as 'unindicted co-conspirators' was largely a tactical move by the government." A June 2008 ACLU press release states, "The prosecutor also acknowledged that the public labeling was simply a 'legal tactic' intended to allow the government to introduce hearsay evidence against HLF later at trial."" Additionally, James Jacks, the U.S. Attorney who led the prosecution of the Holy Land Foundation wrote in a statement published on April 29, 2011 in the Dallas Morning News: "'The decision to indict or not indict a case is based upon an analysis of the evidence and the law,' [Jacks] wrote. 'That's what happened in this case.'"

data.assertion: How consistently do Muslims condemn violence?
data.fact:
FACT: Major Muslim leaders and organizations in the U.S. and around the world have consistently condemned violence against civilians in clear terms, including the U.S. Council of Muslim Organizations and the Union of Islamic Organizations of France, among many others.

'The Bridge Institute' at Georgetown University, which tracks condemnations of violence released by Muslim organizations, has written, "To date, we've identified condemnations from more than 80 religious, civil, and political organizations, from 92 countries on six continents. From Argentina to Canada, from Alaska to Australia, Muslims have denounced ISIS. There are dozens of local student groups, tens of dozens of online campaigns and joint statements, and scores of public demonstrations and protests. Government leaders from the top 10 countries with the largest Muslim populations have condemned the group, as have some 14 Grand Muftis (the highest official of religious law in Sunni Muslim countries)."

Over 120 prominent Muslim scholars from around the world have written an open letter to ISIS, denouncing the group as un-Islamic. This letter condemns the use of violence against innocents and rejects the use of Islamic scripture to justify extremism.

In his remarks to a 2015 White House summit, President Barack Obama spoke about the "respected Muslim clerics and scholars not just here in the United States but around the world" who reject groups such as ISIS. President Obama goes on to say that these Muslim leaders "want to make very clear what Islam stands for. And we're joined by some of these leaders today. These religious leaders and scholars preach that Islam calls for peace and for justice, and tolerance toward others..."

Additionally, according to an August 2011 Gallup poll report titled "Muslim Americans: Faith, Freedom and Future," compared to members of other major religions as well as atheists and agnostics, American Muslims are by far the staunchest opponents of attacks on civilians, with 78% saying that military attacks are never justified and 89% saying that attacks on civilians by individuals or small groups are never justified. A 2013 Pew Research survey of Muslims worldwide found that "Muslims around the world strongly reject violence in the name of Islam."

data.assertion: What is the meaning of the Arabic word 'Jihad'?
data.fact:
FACT: A Gallup poll report that surveyed a cross section of the world's 1.2 billion Muslims and asked what 'jihad' meant to them.The most frequently articulated descriptions described "duty toward God" or "worship of God" with "no militaristic connotation." Other frequent definitions included "a commitment to hard work," "living in the principals of Islam" and "promoting peace, harmony, or cooperation and assisting others." The author of this Gallup poll report noted that jihad should not be identified with the concept of 'Holy War,' which is "originally grounded in Christendom, tracing its lineage (ironically) back to the Crusades."

In the book, "Essential Islam: A Comprehensive Guide to Belief and Practice", author Diane Morgen explains that the Islamic theological definition of jihad is to "struggle in the way of God" and there are two forms of jihad. The first is the "greater jihad", or the inner struggle against one's own evil impulses, such as greed, anger and malice. "Greater jihad" includes doing good works and charity in accordance with the will of God. The second form of jihad is "lesser jihad", or physical struggle against injustice in the world. It is important to note that this is not just a scholarly definition: this is how the majority of more than a billion Muslims worldwide understand jihad. This description agrees with the findings of Gallup poll report on what jihad means to everyday Muslims around the world.
